items.title: Microsoft shares fall despite beating cloud revenue expectations

featured_image.name: Microsoft Q2 earnings beat on top and bottom lines as cloud ...

items.description:
Microsoft reported stronger-than-expected quarterly results on Wednesday, but its shares fell more than 7% in extended trading as investors questioned whether the tech giant's cloud growth justifies the scale of its artificial intelligence investments.[1][2]

The company posted fiscal second-quarter revenue of $81.3 billion, up 17% year-over-year and slightly above the $80.3 billion analysts had expected. Earnings per share of $5.16 also beat Wall Street estimates of $3.92. Azure, the cloud computing division closely watched by investors, grew 39%—narrowly edging past the 38.8% consensus estimate.[3][4][5][1]

items.title: Meta to report Q4 earnings amid AI spending surge, layoffs

featured_image.name: Meta Raises Its Spending Forecast on A.I. to Above $70 Billion

items.description:
Meta Platforms, Inc. will announce its fourth-quarter 2025 earnings after market close Wednesday as Wall Street scrutinizes the social media giant's aggressive artificial intelligence spending and recent workforce cuts in its virtual reality division.

Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg expect the company to report revenue of approximately $58.4 billion, a 21% year-over-year increase, with earnings per share of around $8.16 to $8.21. Bank of America analysts project the company could beat consensus estimates, forecasting revenue of $59.2 billion and EPS of $8.27.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: German chancellor warns weak dollar burdens exporters
items.description:
German Chancellor Friedrich Merz warned Wednesday that the weakening dollar has become a "considerable additional burden" for Germany's export-oriented economy, while calling on Washington to uphold trade commitments made with the European Union last year.

"We will have to assert ourselves globally against a weak dollar and a strong euro," Merz told reporters in Berlin. "We simply have to become more competitive and stronger, especially given the currency exchange rates."[1][2]

items.title: Mexico suspends oil shipments to Cuba amid US pressure

featured_image.name: Mexico's president confirms suspension of oil deliveries to Cuba - UPI

items.description:
Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum confirmed Tuesday that her government has at least temporarily suspended oil shipments to Cuba, a move that comes as the Trump administration intensifies efforts to economically isolate the Caribbean island nation. While Sheinbaum insisted the decision was "sovereign" and not made under pressure from the United States, the timing follows weeks of escalating American rhetoric demanding an end to Cuba's energy lifelines.[1][2][3][4]

State oil company Petróleos Mexicanos (Pemex) was scheduled to send a crude shipment aboard the vessel Swift Galaxy in mid-January but removed the cargo from its schedule without explanation, according to documents reviewed by Bloomberg. The cancellation leaves Cuba facing deepening fuel shortages and extended blackouts, with the island already producing only half the electricity it needs.[5][1]

items.title: Live: Wall Street drifts as Fed leaves rates on hold, ASX poised for flat opening
items.description: The US Fed's decision to hold interest rates has kept a lid on Wall Street trading and the ASX is set to follow suit with an expected flat opening. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

items.title: East Africa faces drought and faster tectonic rifting as south floods

featured_image.name: Giant crack opens in East African Rift Valley - Temblor.net

items.description: East Africa is contending with a dual climate crisis: new scientific research shows that millennia of drying conditions are accelerating the continent's tectonic split, while the region confronts a severe drought in the north and catastrophic flooding in the south.

items.description: Nationals leader David Littleproud has pushed back on reports he "rebuffed" a meeting with Sussan Ley to mend the friendship. Follow live.

items.description: The gap between the top seeds and the rest of the players in both the men's and women's draws has resulted in another day filled with straight-sets wipeouts at the Australian Open.

items.title: Federal Reserve holds interest rates steady amid Trump pressure

featured_image.name: Trump wants lower borrowing costs—but a Fed rate cut may be months away

items.description: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday announced it will leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3.5%-3.75%, marking a pause after three consecutive quarter-point cuts late last year. The widely anticipated decision comes as Chair Jerome Powell navigates unprecedented political pressure from President Donald Trump and a Justice Department investigation that Powell has called a "pretext" for influencing monetary policy.

items.title: RBA warned to 'tread carefully' or risk hitting stressed borrowers for six
items.description: The Reserve Bank cut interest rates three times last year, betting inflation would moderate. But that hasn't happened, and now a rate hike looks likely next month — and possibly another in May.

items.title: Travel agents overwhelmed by new UK passport rules
items.description: New passport rules for UK-Australian dual citizens have customers in "tears", say travel agents who are working through the night to help.

items.title: Fast-growing trees threaten forest diversity worldwide, study finds

featured_image.name: Diverse forests are stronger against drought | Stanford ...

items.description:
The world's forests are undergoing a transformation that may weaken their ecological integrity for decades to come. A comprehensive international study published January 27 in Nature Plants warns that fast-growing tree species are increasingly dominating forest ecosystems worldwide, displacing slower-growing native trees and reducing both biodiversity and long-term carbon storage capacity.[1][2][3]

The research team analyzed more than 31,000 tree species globally and found that forests are becoming homogenized as fast-growing varieties such as acacia, eucalyptus, poplar, and pine outcompete specialized native species. Nearly 41 percent of naturalized tree species—those that have established wild populations outside their native ranges—possess traits like rapid growth and small leaves that make them well-suited to disturbed environments but unable to fulfill the ecological roles of the species they replace.[2][4][1]

items.title: MP battling cancer says condemned health agency could have saved him
items.description: Victorian Greens MP Tim Read reveals he will retire from politics at this year's election after he was diagnosed with metastatic cancer — but not before one last political fight.

items.title: Bank of Canada holds rates steady, warns Fed independence threats add to global instability

featured_image.name: Threat to Fed's independence boosts economic uncertainty, says ...

items.description: The Bank of Canada on Wednesday maintained its benchmark interest rate at 2.25 percent, while the U.S. Federal Reserve is widely expected to keep its policy rate unchanged in the 3.5-3.75 percent range when it announces its decision later today. Both central banks are navigating elevated uncertainty, with Governor Tiff Macklem warning that threats to the Fed's independence add to global economic instability.[1][2][3]

items.title: Leaked draft shows Trump's Gaza board would grant him sweeping power

featured_image.name: What we know about Trump's Gaza plan

items.description:
A leaked document has revealed that President Donald Trump's newly established Board of Peace would grant him extraordinary authority over Gaza's governance, reconstruction, and legal framework, drawing sharp criticism from humanitarian leaders and sparking divisions among U.S. allies.

The unsigned draft resolution, dated January 22 and obtained by Drop Site News from three independent sources, shows that Trump would serve as chairman with power to sign all resolutions into force, approve military commanders, and appoint key officials throughout the governing apparatus. The document states the Board would hold "all transitional legislative and executive authority, emergency powers, and the administration of justice" over Gaza.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump warns Iran 'time is running out' as US naval fleet approaches

featured_image.name: US-Iran latest: Trump says 'massive armada' heading to Iran - and warns 'time is running out'

items.description:
President Donald Trump issued an urgent ultimatum to Iran on Wednesday, warning that "time is running out" to negotiate a nuclear agreement as a massive US naval fleet approaches the region. The warning escalates tensions weeks after deadly protests rocked Iran and following last year's US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

"Hopefully Iran will quickly 'come to the table' and negotiate a fair and equitable deal — NO NUCLEAR WEAPONS — one that is good for all parties," Trump wrote in a social media post, according to Reuters. "Time is running out, it is truly of the essence!"[1][2]

Trump explicitly referenced the previous US military strikes on Iran, warning that "the next attack will be far worse" if Tehran does not comply. The president also noted that a "huge armada is making its way to Iran with great speed and power" and would "fulfill its mission with speed and violence if necessary".[3][4][5][6]

items.description: Amid fits and starts, Australia's energy transition turned a big corner in 2025, as renewables shot past fossil fuels despite demand records.
